title: Is chaos really fair? Why or why not? - Quora

response.answer_text: There is a Biblical statement regarding this issue. In Matthew 5:45, as part of the Sermon on the Mount, Jesus says this about God the Father: “He makes his sun rise on the evil and on the good, and sends rain on the just and on the unjust” Another Biblical passage that more or less “targets only the unjust” can be seen in a number of stories. As soon as Moses had finished saying all this, the ground beneath them split open, Numbers 16:33 They went down alive into Sheol with all they owned. The earth closed over them, and they vanished from the assembly. Numbers 16:49 But those who died from the plague numbered 14,700, in addition to those who had died on account of Korah. We can find more where the precision of focusing in is to punish only the unjust. The “idea of fairness” may be an anthropomorphic grasp about our “lower case” mortal lives. In an eternal sense, this world is “temporary” and is more like a “projection” of an eternal soul that is not destroyed. So, in an eternal sense, chaos here would be fair, but there would also be “lessons” where “order” is included “down here.” Given that there is a sort of tug of war between chaos/order, it would be nice if order wins out, even in a temporal world. But if we can be seated as Monday Morning quarterbacks, with a celestial audience to stare back in retrospect with a 2020 vision, to probe and judge the world, “chaos” may spread like a disease with no concern from life forms, or it can have those opposed to help spread “order.” The “chaos” itself is neutral, and in that sense “fair.” It is when species, like human beings deal with chaos that we have to face the reality that human beings are not the only game in town.

I’d say fairness is pretty specific to conscious entities that concern themselves with notions of morality. Entropy doesn’t care about being fair, and a lion isn’t eating you because it thinks you deserve to be eaten (it eats you because it is hungry). However if we think in a bit more of a statistical sense I would say chaos could be considered “fair” - it doesn’t really differentiate between outcomes nor does it preference particular trends. Any patterns that do occur in a truly chaotic system are flukes of chance. For example take the hypothetical of a group of people falling into a pool of water, that has multiple conflicting currents running through it. A chaotic swirl that could only be predicted or simulated with a supercomputer and a lot of fine tuning of parameters. The pool of water will treat every person who falls into it in the same fashion - they’ll get tossed about in seemingly random directions, some may get hurt, others may escape unharmed. While other factors might influence the outcome (swimming ability, landing on the edge of the pool vs at the center, etc), the water itself will behave no differently to any particular individual. It merely flows and pushes whatever is in those flows around. Actually, getting tossed into a pool of conflicting currents could be a decent analogy for life, thinking about it.
